Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: I was scrubbing the hospital corridor, gloved hands aching, when my phone buzzed with frantic messages from my activist group. The protest downtown had taken a turn—police were blocking exits, and panic was rising. As a cleaner, I was drilled to never leave my post without properly sanitizing, never remove my gloves or mask, and always follow protocol. But as an activist, I was expected to be present, to help coordinate a safe, calm response, to protect my friends and the cause we all believed in. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Safety first, always.” But my friend’s text—“We need you now, people are scared”—pulled at my heart. I stared at my gloved hands, torn between the sterile world of my job and the urgent, messy reality outside. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I felt frozen, caught between duty and conviction, unable to move.
